JavaScript vs. Ruby

JavaScript Objects vs. Ruby Hashes

October 1, 2015

Objects are important to programming because they store data and can be used to represent something. In JavaScript these objects are a crucial data structure in storing and organizing relevant information. The stored data within an object is known as object properties. The collection of properties are often characteristics or attributes of the given object at hand. Objects can also have methods associated with them.

Example JavaScript Object

JavaScript combines these properties within a single object. The properties in effect represent key value pairs which can be access, edited, or deleted at a later time. You can even nest properties within properties.

Adding a JavaScript Property

Deleting a JavaScript Property

How do JavaScript objects compare to Ruby hashes?

Ruby Hashes are very similar to JavaScript objects in the fact that hashes themselves are objects. They list a series of key-value pairs similar to the properties of JavaScript objects. In addition, Ruby hashes can be accessed, edited, deleted, and nested as well.

Example Ruby Hash

However, there is a difference in the ways the values are accessed in JavaScript and Ruby when referencing these objects. Ruby has a strict bracket notation, which follows the format of accessing elements from an array. The value within the bracket signifies the key within the hash that you want to call the value of. Whereas in JavaScript, there is the existence of both a dot notation (which more closely resembles the bracket notation of Ruby) and a bracket notation which is used to evaluate the value in the bracket and uses the result as the property name.

Accessing a Ruby Hash

Accessing a JavaScript Object

As a wise man once said, there is no better or worse -- only different.
